Article.ArticleTitle: Identification of close relationship between large-scale circulation patterns and ozone-precursor sensitivity in the Pearl River Delta, China.

AbstractText: To curb the continuous deterioration of ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) pollution in China, identifying the O<sub>3</sub>-precursor sensitivity (OPS) and its driving factors is a prerequisite for formulating effective O<sub>3</sub> pollution control measures. Traditional OPS identification methods have limitations in terms of spatiotemporal representation and timeliness; therefore, they are not appropriate for making OPS forecasts for O<sub>3</sub> contingency control. OPS is not only influenced by local precursor emissions but is also closely related to meteorological conditions governed by large-scale circulation (LSC). In this study, a localized three-dimensional numerical modeling system was used to investigate the relationship between LSC and OPS in the Pearl River Delta (PRD) of China during September 2017, a month with continuous O<sub>3</sub> pollution. Our results highlighted that there was a close relationship between LSC and OPS over the PRD, and the four dominant LSC patterns corresponded well to the NO<sub>x</sub>-limited, NO<sub>x</sub>-limited, VOC-limited, and transitional regimes, respectively. The clear linkage between LSC and OPS was mainly driven by the spatial heterogeneity of NO<sub>x</sub> and VOC emissions within and beyond the PRD along the prevailing winds under different LSC patterns. A conceptual model was developed to highlight the intrinsic causality between the LSC and OPS. Because current technology can accurately forecast LSC 48-72 h in advance, the LSC-based OPS forecast method provided us with a novel approach to guide contingency control and management measures to reduce peak O<sub>3</sub> at a regional scale.
